http://sws.geonames.org/1814991/ Zidong Wei (School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University) received Bachelor degree from Shaanxi University of Science and Technology (1984), and Ph.D. degree from Tianjin University (1994). He has been in the field of electrochemical catalysis for more than 30 years and has published more than 300 papers with citation over 22000 times. He has been the Chief Scientist of the National Key Research and Development Program and the Chief Scientist of the National Natural Science Foundation. He edited or participated in the compilation of \u201CElectrochemical Catalysis\u201D, \u201CChemical Process Intensification\u201D, \u201CElectrocatalysis\u201D, \u201CElectrocatalytic Oxygen Reduction Reaction\u201D and other books. He won the first, second and third prizes of provincial and ministerial level natural sciences and technological progress once each. He is a council member in the Chemical Industry and Engineering Society of China, and Chinese Chemical Society. Metal-nitrogen-carbon single-atom catalysts (M-N-C SACs) have emerged as pivotal in catalysis due to their unique geometric structures, electronic states, and catalytic capabilities. Notably, the incorporation of magnetic elements at the active centers of these single-atom catalysts has garnered attention for their role in efficient electrochemical conversions. The orientation of spin states critically influences the adsorption and formation of reactants and intermediates, making the precise control of spin alignment and magnetic moments essential for reducing energy barriers and overcoming spin-related limitations, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. Thus, understanding the catalytic role of spin and modulating spin density at M-N-C single-atom centers holds profound fundamental and technological significance. In this review, we elucidate the fundamental mechanisms governing spin states and its influence in electrocatalysis. We then discuss various strategies for adjusting the spin states of active centers in the M-N-C SACs and the associated characterization techniques. Finally, we outline challenges and future perspectives of spin regulation for high-performance catalysts. This review provides deep insights into the micro-mechanisms of catalytic phenomena and offers a roadmap for designing spin-regulated catalysts for advanced energy applications. Graphical Abstract This review covers recent advances in spin regulation of M-N-C single-atom catalysts, focusing on spin state mechanisms, catalyst design strategies, characterization techniques, and future challenges for developing high-performance catalysts for energy and environmental applications. Keywords Electrocatalysis M-N-C materials Single-atom catalyst Electron spin effect Spin regulation 1 Introduction As global energy consumption continues to rise, addressing the depletion of fossil fuels and excessive CO2 emissions through the development of renewable energy sources has become imperative [ 1,2 ]. Various energy conversion and storage devices, such as metal-air batteries (MABs), water electrolysis units, and fuel cells, are being extensively researched in this context. Efficient electrocatalysts play a crucial role in enhancing the efficiency of these devices. Currently, precious metal catalysts are the most used, but their scarcity and high cost significantly restrict their widespread application in energy conversion devices. Therefore, finding precious metal-free alternatives has become a priority, with substantial efforts focused on developing catalysts composed solely of abundant earth elements. In recent years, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have emerged as a highly active area of catalytic research due to their maximum atomic utilization and unique catalytic activity [ 3,4 ]. Theoretically, SACs offer nearly 100% metal dispersion and a unique metal coordination environment, providing maximum atomic efficiency and distinct catalytic properties compared to metal nanocatalysts [ 5–7 ]. Additionally, the uniformity of active sites and clear reaction pathways in SACs significantly enhance selectivity, facilitating more efficient chemical reactions and energy conversion processes [ 8–10 ]. Supported metal SACs, particularly metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) electrocatalysts, demonstrate higher catalytic activity and selectivity than bulk materials by stabilizing metal single atoms (SAs) at nitrogen sites within the carbon matrix. The incorporation of nitrogen atoms into the carbon lattice disrupts the preexisting undifferentiated conjugated structure, leading to a non-uniform electron density distribution that enhances electron transfer and catalytic performance [ 11,12 ]. Enhancing catalytic activity can be achieved through two primary approaches. Firstly, by increasing the loading of metal SAs or optimizing support exposure to enhance surface area and thereby the number of active sites. Secondly, by modifying the electronic structure of active sites to augment their intrinsic activity [ 13,14 ]. To date, the main strategies for enhancing SA catalytic performance have focused on increasing SA loading and tuning their coordination environments. However, these methods often encounter challenges such as particle aggregation and poorly defined synergistic mechanisms. The low loading and instability of metal SACs reduce electrocatalytic efficiency, often leading to aggregation of isolated metal atoms due to high surface energies and weak interactions with substrates [ 15 ]. In recent years, there has been increasing interest in regulating spin alignment and magnetic moment due to their significant influence on adsorption and intermediate formation in reactions, which can lower energy barriers or overcome spin inhibition, ultimately impacting catalytic activity. SACs, with their unique electronic structure and each active site consisting of a single metal atom, provide an ideal platform for studying spin regulation [ 16,17 ]. Here, the spin state and spin-orbit coupling effects play a critical role in catalytic reactions. Spin-polarized electrons within SACs facilitate the formation of oxygen with parallel spins through quantum spin exchange interactions (QSEI). This process converts the non-reactive triplet state of free radical pairs into the reactive singlet state [ 18,19 ], thereby enhancing the reaction probability. Additionally, modifying the spin state of the active center directly influences the occupancy of d-orbitals, which regulates the strength of metal-ligand bonds and the adsorption behavior of reaction intermediates [ 20 ]. Lin and colleagues [ 21 ] demonstrated that the spin state of a single transition metal (TM) atom systematically varies with the coordination of adjacent nitrogen or oxygen atoms. They achieved this by anchoring well-isolated TM atoms at atomic defects dispersed within graphene. Notably, the structure formed by iron atoms and four adjacent nitrogen atoms (Fe+4N) resembles the binding site for oxygen molecules in hemoglobin. This configuration enables the capture and release of oxygen molecules by transitioning the spin state of iron atoms from low to high. Thus, enhancing the catalytic performance of SACs by regulating the spin state of the active center represents a promising strategy [ 22,23 ]. Various approaches effectively manage the spin state of metal ions, with recombination and doping being prominent techniques. Compositional changes lead to variations in valence states, magnetism, and spin moments of elements [ 24 ]. Fine-tuning the spin state of SACs can be achieved through heteroatom doping, control of coordination numbers, clustering with SAs, and diatomic synergies, significantly impacting their catalytic performance [ 25 ]. These methods alter the electronic structure and spin characteristics of SACs through distinct mechanisms, optimizing reaction pathways and enhancing catalyst activity and selectivity [ 26 ]. For example, substituting metal center coordination sites with different nitrogen heteroatoms can modulate electronic affinity and coordination environments, thereby altering spin states and enhancing catalyst activity. Adjusting the coordination number of the metal center, from four to five or six, can also change the electronic structure and distribution of spin states of metal ions, optimizing intermediate state stability during reactions and enhancing catalyst selectivity. Combining monatomic metal ions with small metal clusters, such as metal oxide clusters, allows for adjusting electron distribution within clusters and interactions between metal ions, influencing surface active sites and catalytic properties. Introducing two distinct metal atoms into the catalyst, such as the bimetallic synergy of copper and platinum, effectively modulates the electronic structure, enhancing both activity and selectivity in oxygen reduction reactions. These approaches demonstrate promising potential in monatomic catalysis, providing a theoretical foundation and technical support for developing highly efficient, low-cost catalysts [ 7,27,28 ]. While numerous methods have been developed for the fabrication and design of various M-N-C SACs, and several reviews have explored SACs broadly [ 29 ], few have specifically emphasized the impact of spin state regulation on the electrocatalytic activity of M-N-C SACs. This article aims to fill this gap by providing a comprehensive review of recent advancements in spin regulation techniques for M-N-C SACs in electrocatalysis, with the goal of enhancing their performance [ 30 ]. In this review, we first elucidate the fundamental mechanisms governing the spin state of SAs [ 31 ]. We then provide detailed discussions on four primary strategies for manipulating the spin state of SAs within M-N-C SACs: heteroatom doping, coordination number regulation, cluster-monomer recombination, and diatomic synergy (Fig. 1 ). We analyze how each strategy influences catalytic performance. Additionally, we explore characterization techniques used to study spin states in these catalysts. Finally, we outline the current challenges and prospects of spin-regulated SACs in advancing electrocatalytic applications. 2 Basic principles between spin state and catalysis 2.1 Kinetic principles Chemical reactions are governed by two fundamental parameters: energy (free energy and activation energy) and angular momentum (spin) of the reactants [ 32 ]. The conservation of total angular momentum in chemical reactions is a fundamental and universal principle, leading to electron and nuclear spin selectivity. Only spin states where the spin of the reactants matches that of the products are chemically active. Chemical reactions are prohibited if the conversion of reactants to products necessitates a change in spin [ 33,34 ]. The mechanisms by which electron and nuclear spins control reactions are well understood. This mechanism can be illustrated through the example of triplet radical pairs (R,R), generated by processes such as photodissociation, radiolysis, or encounters between freely diffusing radicals [ 35 ]. To recombine and form the diamagnetic zero-spin molecule R,R, a triplet-to-singlet spin transition of the radical pair is necessary [ 36 ] (Figs. 2(a) and (b)). During this phase, chemical reactions are spin-state dependent. Spin conversion and triplet-singlet evolution are influenced by Zeeman interactions, hyperfine (electron-nuclear or Fermi) coupling, magnetic interactions with microwaves (if applied), and exchange interactions between ligands of free radical pairs and external third-spin carriers. These interactions are fundamental in electron spin catalysis [ 37,38 ]. An applied magnetic field can adjust Zeeman energy, alter the spin states of ions and intermediates, align ion spins, create spin channels, and enhance catalytic performance. In particular, a moderate magnetic field applied externally via a permanent magnet or embedded via ferromagnetic additives can modify the properties of reaction precursors, intermediates, products, and the catalyst itself. This modification improves catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability [ 39,40 ]. Theoretical studies, such as those by Gracia [ 41 ], demonstrate that spin-polarized electrons in the catalyst promote the generation of oxygen with parallel spin alignment through QSEI, thereby enhancing oxygen evolution reaction (OER) kinetics. These interactions, through spin alteration, convert the non-reactive triplet state of free radical pairs into the reactive singlet state, thereby increasing the likelihood of reaction. A prominent example is molecular oxygen (O2), which typically exists in a ground state paramagnetic triplet with two parallel spin electrons in the 2pπ* orbital, while oxygen-containing compounds and intermediates in electrocatalytic processes often adopt the singlet state [ 42 ]. According to spin selection rules, singlet atomic groups can recombine into diamagnetic molecules, whereas triplet atomic groups cannot. Therefore, spin-dependent electron transfer plays a crucial role in reaction kinetics. In reactions involving O2, spin inversion in reactants or catalysts, such as in the OER and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), is essential. Engineering spin alignment and magnetic moments can thus lower energy barriers or overcome spin inhibition, a concept known as spin catalysis [ 43 ]. Additionally, magnetic OER catalysts typically exhibit a slight enhancement in reaction current density when subjected to an external magnetic field, as the magnetic field facilitates the parallel alignment of oxygen radicals and promotes the formation of trilinear molecular oxygen [ 44 ]. Peng et al. [ 45 ] investigated the symmetry between the upper and lower local density state (PDOS) fields of the NiCo2(OH) x , NiCo2(SOH) x , and NiCo2S4 models (Fig. 2(c)), revealing that catalysts with different ligands exhibit varying magnetic properties that significantly impact the OER process. The paramagnetic O2 produced on the surface of magnetic catalysts generates an attractive force, making O2 desorption more challenging. Furthermore, the coexistence of sulfur (S) and hydroxyl (OH) groups influences the electronic environment of the metal atoms. In the optimal Co3(SOH) x configuration, anti-ferromagnetic characteristics elevate the O2 adsorption free energy, leading to a smoother desorption pathway. Results from temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments indicate that the non-magnetic NiCo2(SOH) x facilitates significantly easier O2 desorption, showcasing the smoothest reaction kinetics and the highest OER activity. These findings offer valuable insights for the design of spin-regulated catalysts, suggesting that future research could enhance OER performance by optimizing ligands and magnetic properties, ultimately advancing renewable energy technologies [ 45 ]. 2.2 Thermodynamic principles The spin state of M-N-C catalysts is closely tied to their catalytic activity. M-N-C structures typically form octahedral configurations through metal-nitrogen coordination. TM atoms bond within these octahedra, with their valence orbitals typically comprising nd, (n + 1)s, and (n + 1)p orbitals, where n = 3, 4, or 5. Electrons in these d orbitals experience repulsion from ligands [ 46 ]. To achieve bonding, metal atoms utilize six equivalent hybrid orbitals within the octahedral structure. This involves combining all s and p functions along with two d functions. The electron configuration in the d orbitals is influenced by crystal field splitting energy (Δ0) and electron pairing energy (P). This splitting results in two groups of d orbitals with different energy levels: the lower energy d xy , d xz, and d yz orbitals (collectively referred to as t2g), and the higher energy d z² and d x²–y² orbitals (collectively referred to as eg) [ 47 ] (Fig. 3(a) ). Regulating the spin state of the active center directly influences the occupancy of d orbitals, thereby affecting the strength of metal-ligand bonds and the adsorption behavior of intermediates [ 48,49 ]. The eg orbitals of TM ions participate in σ-bonding with intermediates and influence charge transfer at the catalytic interface, making their occupancy crucial for binding and reaction thermodynamics at active sites [ 50,51 ]. Spin state regulation can adjust the electron occupancy in eg orbitals. For 3d metal-based SACs, particularly Co and Fe-based SACs, the spin state of the active center correlates with Δ0 and P. When Δ0 exceeds P, electrons preferentially pair in low-energy orbitals, forming low-spin (LS) complexes. Conversely, when P exceeds Δ0, electrons tend to transition from low-energy to high-energy orbitals, forming high-spin (HS) complexes. Due to the relatively similar values of Δ0 and P for Co and Fe ions, various spin states can be achieved through deliberate regulatory strategies (Figs. 3(b)–(d)) [ 52 ]. Liu and colleagues have demonstrated through density functional theory (DFT) calculations that the hybridization between the Fe 3d z², 3d yz (3d xz) orbitals and the O2 π* orbital plays a crucial role in the ORR activity at the Fe-N4 site. They established a direct relationship between the electronic structure of the Fe-N4 site and its ORR activity. From an electronic structure perspective, parameters such as the d-band center energy gap (Δd), the magnetic moment of the Fe site (MFe), and the O2 (MO2) exhibit a nearly linear correlation with the ORR activity of the Fe-N4 site. Liu and colleagues observed that these descriptors and the ORR activity of Fe-N4 are closely associated, reflecting the hybridization between the Fe 3d z², 3d yz (3d xz) orbitals and the O2 π* orbital, which significantly enhances ORR activity [ 53 ]. Yang et al. [ 54 ] investigated the effects of spin and thermodynamics on the catalytic activity of the ORR in doped graphene. The introduction of dual carbon active sites, formed by heteroatoms such as N, phosphorus (P), or boron (B), enhances O2 dissociation efficiency, lowers the energy barrier, and facilitates the reaction (Figs. 3(e) and (f)). The change in free energy during O2 dissociation represents the rate-determining step (RDS) of the entire reaction, while the regulation of spin density further influences the thermodynamic properties of the process. By optimizing the type of doping, both charge and spin effects can be simultaneously introduced, significantly improving catalytic performance. This emphasizes the critical role of spin regulation in enhancing the thermodynamic behavior of the catalyst [ 54 ]. 3 Spin regulation strategies of SACs 3.1 Heteroatom doping In heterogeneous catalysis, interactions between reactants and catalysts occur at active sites on solid surfaces [ 54 ]. Increasing the surface atomic ratio of active components, particularly active metals, directly enhances catalytic efficiency [ 55 ]. Theoretically, the surface atomic ratio of metal heterogeneous catalysts can be maximized to 100%, where surface metal atoms are fully exposed. Reducing metal active components to the SA scale maximizes metal utilization in catalysts [ 56 ]. However, zero-valent metal SAs are highly unstable and require solid support materials (such as oxides, zeolites, carbon, heteroatom-doped carbon, etc.) to anchor atoms like O, C, N, S, and P. These form chemical bonds with single metal atoms, creating stable SA metal sites. Support materials also enhance conductivity and help control spin [ 57,58 ]. Heteroatom doping significantly alters the electronic structure and spin density distribution of SACs, thereby regulating their catalytic performance [ 59 ]. Heteroatoms with varying electronegativities and electron configurations change electron density and spin distribution in SACs, altering the local electronic environment and potentially inducing spin polarization, which affects the catalyst's spin state. These changes profoundly impact the selectivity and activity of catalytic reactions [ 60,61 ]. Recent research indicates that breaking the symmetry of the planar Fe-N4 structure through heteroatom doping (e.g., S, P, B) effectively adjusts its electronic structure, optimizing the adsorption strength of intermediate products and thereby enhancing ORR activity [ 62,63 ]. Chen and colleagues have demonstrated that doping adjacent S atoms into the Fe1-N-C catalyst induces a transition to a spin-polarized configuration (Fig. 4(a) ), leading to a predominance of LS state Fe3+ in Fe1-NS1.3C, which exhibits superior ORR activity compared to conventional Fe-N-C materials. Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy and DFT calculations suggest that these C-FeN4-S sites, with LS single Fe3+ atoms, serve as active sites for ORR. The presence of adjacent S atoms allows Fe3+ to adopt the LS state, which facilitates the desorption process of the key intermediate OH*, thereby improving ORR efficiency (Fig. 4(b)). The durability of Fe1-NS1.3C was assessed through ORR polarization curves over 10000 cycles, showing negligible decrease in E 1/2 and minimal change in kinetic current density. Methanol tolerance, another critical metric [ 64 ], demonstrated that Fe1-NS1.3C maintained its current without significant decline after methanol addition, unlike Pt/C, which showed noticeable decay. Additionally, chronometric current measurements (i-t) indicated that Fe1-NS1.3C exhibited better durability than Pt/C, with only a 13% loss in relative current density after continuous operation for over 25000 seconds, compared to a significant 34% loss for Pt/C. Comparative studies of ORR activity between Fe1-NS1.3C and SA non-precious metal catalysts (Mn, Fe, Co, Cu, etc.) and TM nanoparticle catalysts revealed that Fe1-NS1.3C exhibited superior activity in most cases (Fig. 4(c)) [ 65 ]. The study utilized Mössbauer spectroscopy and DFT calculations to verify the spin polarization transition induced by doping adjacent S atoms in the Fe1-NS1.3C catalyst, demonstrating that the presence of S atoms allows Fe3+ to adopt a LS state, thereby enhancing the ORR activity. Iron-nitrogen-carbon materials (Fe-N-Cs) featuring atomically dispersed FeN4 sites have shown significant enhancement in the electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (e-NRR) activity [ 66 ]. Li and colleagues have reported a viable strategy to control the local spin state of isolated iron sites through S-coordination doping, termed FeSA-NSC (Figs. 4(d) and (e)). Incorporating S into the FeSA-NSC coordination induces a transition to a spin-polarized configuration, specifically forming an intermediate spin state of Fe (t2g 6 eg 1). This configuration facilitates the penetration of eg electrons through the antibonding π orbitals of nitrogen. Experimental and theoretical analyses confirm that S doping leads to monovalent Fe(I) atomic centers in FeSA-NSC, accelerating the activation and protonation of N2 in the rate-determining step from *N2 to *NNH. Introducing S-coordinating atoms separates Fe-N groups and adjusts the central Fe atom's spin state from high spin to intermediate spin. In this intermediate spin state, Fe(I) acts as the active site, effectively activating the N≡N triple bond in the e-NRR process. Systematic analysis demonstrates that isolated FeN3S1 sites lower the energy barrier for *NNH intermediate formation, accelerate hydrogenation kinetics, and promote electroreduction of N2 to NH3. FeSA-NSC exhibits excellent electrocatalytic performance for e-NRR, achieving an NH3 yield of 30.4 μg h–1 mg–1 cat. at –0.4 V, with a Faraday efficiency (FE) of 21.9%. This efficiency significantly surpasses that of most reported iron-based e-NRR electrocatalysts to date (Fig. 4(f)). Notably, when used in a flow battery electrolyzer, the catalyst also achieves a high current density of 10 mA cm–2 and approximately 10% NH3 selectivity [ 67 ]. In summary, the interaction between heteroatom doping and the spin state of SACs is intricate and crucial. Through rational design and control of heteroatom doping, it becomes possible to effectively manipulate the spin state of SACs, thereby optimizing their catalytic performance. However, this introduces complexity into the system, potentially complicating the understanding and prediction of spin state control mechanisms. Furthermore, non-uniform doping can lead to inconsistencies in spin states, which may adversely affect catalytic performance. In practical applications, meticulous consideration must be given to the design and regulation of heteroatoms, including their type, concentration, and distribution. This approach aims to maximize their beneficial effects while minimizing any negative impacts on catalytic activity. 3.2 Coordination number optimization To enhance the catalytic performance of catalysts, extensive research has focused on understanding the local coordination environment, especially in the realm of SACs, where investigations have progressed to the atomic scale [ 68,69 ]. The surrounding coordinating atoms around the central metal atom play a critical role in determining its catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability, with particular emphasis on regulating the coordination number [ 70,71 ]. Changes in coordination number directly impact the electronic structure of SACs by influencing the occupation of d orbitals in isolated metal atoms, thereby affecting their spin state. A lower coordination number tends to localize electrons more in the d orbitals, enhancing spin polarization. Conversely, a higher coordination number results in more delocalized electrons, weakening spin polarization. Recent advancements have shown that by adjusting coordinating atoms, coordination numbers, and secondary or higher coordination shells, the spin state of active centers can be tailored, leading to significant enhancements in catalytic performance. These developments open new avenues for advancing the field of SACs [ 72,73 ]. Based on recent studies of Fe-N-C catalysts, the coordination number x of FeN x active sites significantly influences their catalytic performance by regulating the charge distribution and electronic spin state. The FeN4 configuration (x = 4) is widely recognized as the primary active center [ 12,74 ]. However, the impact of other coordination configurations of FeN x active sites on catalysis remains unclear and controversial [ 75 ]. Xue and colleagues [ 76 ] addressed this gap by synthesizing three SA Fe-N-C catalysts with well-defined N coordination environments using a template-assisted self-assembly pyrolysis method. They achieved Fe-N5, Fe-N4, and Fe-N3 configurations at different pyrolysis temperatures (800, 1000, and 1100 °C, respectively) (Fig. 5(a) ). Their study demonstrated that adjusting the N coordination number around Fe centers effectively optimizes the electronic spin state, ORR energy, and kinetics. The Fe-N4-4 structure, featuring two parallel coordinating pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N ligands, exhibited a high electron spin state (Fe-N4-HS) (Fig. 5(b)). DFT+U calculations elucidated how this configuration enhances O2 adsorption by facilitating electron penetration into the antibonding π orbitals of oxygen. Consequently, the Fe-N4-HS catalyst showed excellent acidic/basic ORR activity, with an onset potential of 1.051 V in 0.1 mol L–1 HClO4 and a half-wave potential of 0.916 V vs. RHE. Importantly, it demonstrated superior durability in 0.1 mol L–1 KOH compared to commercial Pt/C catalysts (Fig.5(c)). The enhanced stability of the Fe-N4-HS catalyst can be attributed to the optimized Fe–N bond length, which improves structural stability [ 76 ]. These findings underscore the critical role of N coordination configurations in tuning the electronic structure and spin state of Fe-N-C catalysts, offering insights for the development of high-performance ORR electrocatalysts. The experiments utilized DFT+U calculations to verify the role of the Fe-N coordination environment in regulating the electronic spin state, revealing that the high-spin state in the Fe-N4-HS structure enhances oxygen adsorption, thereby improving ORR activity. SACs with controlled coordination numbers can be applied to the reductive amination of biomass-derived aldehydes/ketones for the selective synthesis of primary amines [ 77 ]. Qi and colleagues prepared highly active, selective, and robust Ru SACs supported on nitrogen-doped carbon using a simple pyrolysis method. As the pyrolysis temperature was increased from 700 to 900 °C, the Ru-N coordination number decreased from RuN5 and RuN4 to RuN3 (Fig. 5(d)). They found that the oxidation state of the Ru SAs was +2, but the electron density increased with the decrease in Ru-N coordination number, attributed to the electron-energizing effect of adjacent C atoms. Even in the presence of strongly pre-adsorbed NH3, hydrogen activation gradually enhanced. After further treatment with NH3 at 800 °C, the electron density at the RuN3 sites further increased. The study results demonstrated that the selectivity for primary amines was significantly improved, reaching up to 99% (Fig. 5(e)). Additionally, the Ru1/NC SAC with the RuN3 structure not only exhibited the highest methanol production per Ru atom per hour but also showed greater resistance to the toxicity of sulfur and CO, as well as higher tolerance to harsh treatments such as hydrogen reduction at 600 °C, compared to traditional Ru/AC and other state-of-the-art Ru nanocatalysts [ 78 ]. Moreover, SACs with controlled coordination numbers find applications in the NRR [ 79 ]. Han et al. [ 80 ] employed DFT calculations to systematically explore the impact of coordination numbers on the performance of Fe SACs in NRR. They investigated configurations where Fe was anchored to N x O4–x -C, N4–x C x -C, and C4–x O x -C, varying x to alter the coordination number (Fig. 5(f)). Their findings revealed that the presence of O coordination enhanced N2 adsorption but compromised Fe binding stability. Increasing the number of O atoms decreased binding stability, especially noticeable in the Fe-N x O4–x -C system. N coordination stabilized Fe binding to the support but adversely affected the initial hydrogenation step, particularly in the presence of O. In contrast, C in the Fe-C4–x O x -C system was less favorable for N2 activation. Considering stability, reactivity, and competition with *H for N2, Fe-N2C2-C emerged as the most favorable, exhibiting a maximum Gibbs free energy change of 0.75 eV during the first hydrogenation step (Fig. 5(g)). This superior performance was attributed to the regulatory effect of coordinated C and N on the spin polarization of Fe near the Fermi level [ 80,81 ]. The study employed DFT calculations to systematically investigate the impact of coordination number on the performance of Fe SACs in the NRR, demonstrating that the coordination of carbon and nitrogen modulates the spin polarization of Fe near the Fermi level, which significantly influences its catalytic activity. In summary, controlling coordination numbers alters the electronic structure and spin density distribution of SACs. Optimal coordination numbers can enhance catalyst stability and prevent metal atom aggregation. Through precise design and regulation of coordination numbers, the spin state of SACs can be optimized, thereby improving catalytic efficiency and selectivity. However, achieving precise control over the coordination number of SAs poses challenges, necessitating complex synthesis methods and stringent reaction conditions. This complexity increases the difficulty and cost of catalyst preparation. Nonetheless, through extensive research and optimization of synthesis techniques, the advantages of SACs can be maximized while mitigating their limitations, thereby advancing their applications in energy conversion and other critical fields. 3.3 Cluster-monatom hybridization Compared to nanoparticle catalysts, SACs and catalysts containing small clusters of metal atoms have garnered increasing attention due to their favorable coordination environments and high atomic utilization efficiency, which enhance catalytic performance across various reactions [ 82,83 ]. Nanoclusters exhibit characteristics such as small size, numerous active sites, precisely controlled structures, and a large specific surface area. Through structural regulation (isomers), their catalytic performance can be optimized. The hybridization of clusters with SAs can alter the spin density distribution of SACs. Interactions among multiple atoms in the cluster redistribute spin density throughout the structure, influencing the spin state of the SA. This interaction may either enhance or weaken specific spin states, thereby impacting catalytic activity. Additionally, hybridizing clusters with SAs can modify reaction pathways and optimize catalyst selectivity. Certain spin states may prove more stable reaction pathways, and the presence of the cluster can stabilize these states, thereby enhancing reaction selectivity and activity [ 84 ]. The regulation of the electronic distribution of SA metal sites by atomic clusters is an effective strategy for enhancing electrocatalytic activity [ 85 ]. Due to its poor performance in the ORR in acidic electrolytes compared to Pt/C catalysts, Fe SACs have severely hindered their development [ 86 ]. Wei and colleagues [ 87 ] studied an ORR catalyst composed of Pd nanoclusters (PdNC) and Fe SAs (Fe-N-C/PdNC). Experimental studies and theoretical calculations indicate that PdNC induces a transition of the Fe(II) spin state from low spin to intermediate spin, activating the O–O bond through lateral overlap, and achieving a path transition from binding to dissociation, thus enhancing ORR activity (Figs. 6(a,b )). Under acidic conditions, Fe-N-C/PdNC exhibits excellent ORR performance with a remarkable half-wave potential (0.87 V), negligible degradation after 30000 cycles, and a maximum power density of 920 mW cm−2 in a fuel cell, which is superior to Pt/C catalysts [ 87 ]. Catalysts featuring ultra-small clusters and SA sites have garnered significant attention for their efficient atomic utilization [ 88 ]. An et al. [ 89 ] devised a catalyst embedding ultra-small clusters and SA Fe sites within g-C3N4 for catalytic oxidation reactions (Fig. 6(c)). Employing Fe-imidazole complexes (Fe-ICC) and melamine (MA) as precursors, the catalyst was synthesized via one-step pyrolysis. Experimental techniques, including 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), confirmed highly dispersed Fe sites with a substantial Fe loading (18.2 wt%). The study revealed that the localization of 3d orbitals in the catalyst contrasted with the delocalization observed in iron carbides and nitrides. Moreover, the quadrupole splitting of HS Fe(II) suggested a complex coordination environment consistent with expected Fe-N x species. Subsequently, the performance of the FeN x /g-C3N4 catalyst was assessed using the degradation of methylene blue (MB) as a probe reaction under neutral pH conditions. The I-FeN x /g-C3N4-5 catalyst exhibited rapid MB removal in the photo-Fenton reaction, achieving a removal rate of 60.0% within 2 min and 98.9% within 11 min. These catalysts demonstrated robust degradation activity for various organic pollutants in advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), highlighting their potential for practical applications [ 89 ]. The significant advancements in surface SACs and single-cluster catalysts (SCCs) have demonstrated the feasibility of creating homogeneous catalytic active centers on heterogeneous solid surfaces [ 90,91 ], thereby enhancing the synthesis of ammonia. Liu et al. [ 92 ] introduced a novel strategy involving the anchoring of Fe3 clusters on the θ-Al2O3(010) surface as a heterogeneous catalyst for ammonia synthesis, based on first-principles theoretical studies and microkinetic analysis (Figs. 6(d) and (e)). The Fe3 cluster exhibits stable anchoring on the θ-Al2O3(010) surface, leveraging its multistep redox capability, substantial spin polarization, and low oxidation state metal characteristics. This configuration facilitates spin-polarized charge transfer from Fe 3d orbitals to the N2 π* orbitals, effectively activating N2. Partial occupation of the β-spin π* orbital of N2 reduces the N–N bond order and imparts *N2 with radical properties, thereby initiating a novel binding mechanism for N2 activation (Fig. 6(f)). The associative mechanism liberates the turnover frequency (TOF) of ammonia production from the constraints of the Brønsted-Evans-Polanyi (BEP) relationship. Calculations demonstrate that the TOF on Fe3/θ-Al2O3(010) is comparable to that of the Ru B5 site, significantly outperforming the Fe C7 site by two orders of magnitude [ 92 ]. In summary, the hybridization of clusters with SAs significantly affects the spin state of SACs through various mechanisms such as altering the electronic structure, spin density distribution, and spin-orbital coupling effects. By fine-tuning the composition and structure of the clusters, the spin state of SACs can be regulated, thereby enhancing their catalytic efficiency and selectivity. However, this composite structure of clusters may also lead to negative synergistic effects. For example, certain components within the clusters may compete with the reactants for the SAs, thereby reducing the overall efficiency of the catalyst. When designing and applying such composite catalysts, it is essential to consider these factors and optimize the structure and performance of the catalyst. 3.4 Dual atoms cooperation SACs, composed of a lone metal center, often face challenges in breaking linear relationships typical in catalytic processes. These challenges include low metal loading, limited contact area between the SA and support material, and relatively weak interactions [ 30,93,94 ]. In response to these limitations, bimetallic single-atom catalysts (DACs) have emerged as a promising new class of catalysts in recent years [ 95 ]. By leveraging interactions between two metal atoms, DACs can effectively overcome SAC limitations while retaining advantages such as maximum metal site utilization efficiency [ 96,97 ]. Compared to SACs, DACs offer advantages like higher atomic loading, robust interactions between bimetallic sites, and broad applicability across various catalytic processes. The introduction of two metal atoms significantly alters the electronic structure of the SAC. Adjacent atoms can form shared electron pairs or interacting orbitals, influencing the spin state of the SA. The interaction between bimetallic sites does not merely sum individual atomic functions but rather regulates the electronic structure of catalytic active sites, thereby enhancing catalytic performance and enabling diverse applications. A significant aspect of DACs is their cooperative effect between bimetallic sites [ 98,99 ]. This effect can either enhance or reduce local spin density, depending on the interaction type (e.g., covalent, ionic bonds). This alteration impacts the spin state of the SA potentially optimizing catalytic activity. Interaction between the two atoms redistributes d orbitals, altering spin polarization and enhancing spin-orbit coupling [ 100 ]. By tuning spin-orbit coupling strength, the cooperative effect between bimetallic sites influences catalytic reaction kinetics and mechanisms [ 101 ]. The cooperative effect of bimetallic sites can influence the orbital occupancy of metal atoms with varying electronic spin states [ 102,103 ]. Guided by symmetry matching principles, this interaction determines the electron distribution within molecular orbitals, thereby impacting M–O bonds and subsequent electrocatalytic performance [ 100 ]. For instance, Yang et al. [ 104 ] introduced adjacent Mn atoms into the Fe/N-C structure, altering the electron configuration of square planar coordinated FeIII from a low spin state (t2g 5 eg 0) to an intermediate spin state (t2g 4 eg 1), resulting in the addition of two unpaired d electrons (Figs. 7(a) and (b)). Consequently, the single eg electron in the intermediate spin state d z orbital readily transfers to antibonding π orbitals of oxygen, thereby enhancing the ORR performance of Fe, Mn/N-C in both alkaline and acidic environments (E 1/2 of 0.928 V in 0.1 mol L−1 KOH and 0.804 V in 0.1 mol L−1 HClO4). Additionally, substituting Mn with Zn has proven effective in enhancing the ORR activity. Li et al. [ 105 ] developed a bimetallic catalyst, Fe/Zn-N-C, and proposed a unique semi-metallic electronic structure induced by the synergistic effect of Fe and Zn. The introduction of non-magnetic Zn2+ into the atomic site altered the electronic structure of Fe-N-C, shifting it from a semiconductor to a semi-metal. This transformation regulates the degree of spin polarization of Fe, resulting in the spontaneous accumulation of spin-polarized electrons at the Fermi level. This accumulation enhances the adsorption of paramagnetic O2 molecules and facilitates charge transport between the catalyst and the adsorbed species. Furthermore, the protonation energy barrier of the catalyst was increased, with ZnN4 sacrificially protecting the Fe site during the ORR process. Fe/Zn-N-C exhibited outstanding ORR performance in both alkaline and acidic environments, achieving half-wave potentials of 0.906 and 0.806 V, respectively (Figs. 7(c) and (d)). Importantly, after 5000 potential cycles, Fe/Zn-N-C demonstrated excellent stability with only a 12 mV loss [ 105 ]. Metal-nonmetal (or semi-metal) DACs represent a novel class of catalysts composed of a metal atom paired with a nonmetal (or semi-metal) atom. The distinct electronic structures of these metal and nonmetal atoms enable synergistic effects between them [ 106 ]. While previous research has predominantly focused on metal-based catalysts, fewer studies have explored bimetallic combinations involving nonmetals. Metals and nonmetals typically possess contrasting physical and chemical properties, and their juxtaposition in catalysts can play diverse roles in catalytic reactions [ 107 ]. Chen et al. [ 108 ] developed a Fe/Se bimetallic catalyst based on the Se1-NC SAC. The Fe1Se1-NC catalyst features asymmetrically coordinated Fe-N5 groups and SeC2 dual active sites. Experimental findings highlight that the enhanced ORR activity primarily arises from the synergistic interaction between these dual active sites. Introducing Se shifts the binding energies of N 1s and C 1s to higher values. Selenium doping facilitates electron transfer from C or N to selenium. Analysis using 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy reveals the presence of LS Fe3+ and intermediate-spin (MS) Fe2+ configurations in the catalyst. Incorporating Se atoms notably increases the proportion of Fe in the LS spin-polarized configuration, which enhances the adsorption strength of ORR intermediates and improves conductivity [ 108 ]. Comparative analysis of the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves in alkaline solution (Fig. 7(e)) and acidic conditions (Fig. 7(f)) demonstrates that the ORR activity of the Fe1Se1-NC catalyst surpasses that of both Fe1-NC and Se1-NC catalysts, achieving peak performance. Moreover, the synthesized Fe1Se1-NC catalyst exhibits the highest kinetic current density and half-wave potential (Fig. 7(g)) among the catalysts investigated [ 106 ]. The analysis using 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy confirmed the presence of LS Fe3+ and MS Fe2+ in the catalyst, supporting the impact of introducing selenium on the spin polarization of iron, thereby enhancing the catalyst's activity in the ORR. In conclusion, the cooperative effect of bimetallic atoms significantly influences the spin state of SACs through mechanisms such as adjusting electronic structure, spin density, and spin-orbital coupling effects. However, the introduction of bimetallic atoms may introduce multiple reaction pathways, potentially reducing reaction selectivity, especially in multistep reactions where diverse path selection may decrease overall efficiency. Through rational design and coordination regulation of bimetallic atoms, it is feasible to amplify advantages while mitigating disadvantages, thereby enhancing the overall performance of SACs. 4 Characterization methods for spin state To gain a profound understanding of the role of spin in catalysis, several essential characterization methods are employed, including electron spin resonance (ESR), Mössbauer spectroscopy, and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS). These techniques effectively reveal the electronic state of active sites, offering insights into spin dynamics that are pivotal for designing new SA spin catalysts [ 109,110 ]. Moreover, since reactions unfold dynamically in solution, establishing in situ characterization methods is critical. These methods unveil the real-time state of active sites during chemical reactions, providing crucial mechanistic understanding and guiding the development of novel spin catalysts [ 111 ]. 4.1 ESR/EPR ESR/EPR is a magnetic resonance technique that detects the magnetic moments of unpaired electrons. It serves as a crucial tool for studying the state of unpaired electrons in compounds or minerals. ESR's high sensitivity enables the investigation of low-concentration active sites in SACs [ 112 ]. Moreover, ESR measurements are stable and less influenced by surrounding conditions [ 113 ]. Guo et al. [ 114, 115 ] observed changes in the three-dimensional electron spin configuration and chemical environment of Fe2+ in FePc/Ti3C2T x through shifts and variations in ESR signal intensity. The presence of additional unpaired d electrons facilitated the adsorption and reduction of hydrogen peroxide, thereby enhancing the ORR activity of FeN4 SACs. In recent years, the combination of ESR and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) has emerged as a powerful platform for manipulating surface atomic spins (Figs. 8(a), (b) ). This technique offers unprecedented resolution for studying magnetic interactions between pairs of atoms [ 116 ] and the coherence properties of atomic spins [ 117 ], even probing interactions at the SA level [ 118 ]. This has sparked significant theoretical interest in understanding coherence and the mechanisms of surface atomic spin-driven processes, with potential applications in quantum sensing. Willke et al. [ 116 ] demonstrated the control of spin-environment interactions of a single Fe atom using ESR-STM by manipulating tip position and tunneling parameters. Despite phase coherence loss due to current, their study showed that the largest spin resonance signal could be achieved under high tunneling currents, facilitating SA spin resonance as a quantum sensor, as recently shown in measuring the magnetic moment of a SA. Additionally, ESR can be performed at higher temperatures (up to 4 K) and in relatively small magnetic fields, conditions feasible in many low-temperature STM setups. Studying spin resonance across various tunneling currents and temperatures aids in understanding, controlling, and differentiating decoherence mechanisms at the SA level [ 119 ]. Li et al. [ 120 ] investigated changes in the three-dimensional electron spin configuration and chemical environment of Fe2+ in FePc/Ti3C2T x based on shifts and variations in ESR signal intensity. They found that increased unpaired d electrons promoted the adsorption and reduction of hydrogen peroxide, thereby enhancing the ORR activity of FeN4 SACs. In summary, ESR offers advantages such as high sensitivity and detailed information on the spin state of SACs. However, it is limited to detecting paramagnetic centers, involves complex data interpretation, and requires sophisticated equipment. For paramagnetic SACs with unpaired electrons, ESR remains a valuable technique, particularly for studying changes in electronic structure, chemical environment, and spin state. 4.2 Electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) EELS utilizes monochromatic low-energy electrons (20–500 eV) to irradiate surfaces, exciting lattice vibrations of the substrate, molecular vibrations of adsorbed species, and electronic transitions. EELS is effective for probing the chemical state [ 121 ], oxidation state [ 122 ], and coordination number of SAs [ 123 ]. It requires high sample thickness [ 124 ] and is limited to flat surfaces in high vacuum environments. EELS detects all vibrations and offers high sensitivity to local structural changes, achieving atomic column spatial resolution [ 125 ]. Changes in spin states can induce alterations in the local catalyst structure, which are discernible with EELS [ 126 ]. For example, Ma et al. [ 127 ] employed O K-edge EELS to distinguish spin state differences of Co3+ in LaCoO3 between bulk and surface regions. The O K-edge spectra revealed significant differences in peak intensity and energy between surface and bulk areas. The pre-edge peak around 530 eV in the O K-edge correlates closely with the spin state of LaCoO3; higher spin states of Co3+ correspond to lower pre-edge peak intensities. These findings highlight the diversity of Co3+ spin states on the surface compared to the bulk. Moreover, EELS can track spin state transitions of Co3+. Lan et al. [ 125 ] demonstrated this by analyzing the ratio of peak intensities in Co L3 and L2 EELS to confirm Co valence reduction and increased O vacancy concentration in the dark Co-O layer. Theoretical calculations corroborated these observations, showing that doping smaller radius Ca2+ into LaCoO3 thin films converts HS Co3+ to LS states [ 125 ]. Furthermore, the integration of in situ heating transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and high-resolution EELS has emerged as a pivotal technique for investigating spin-charge conversion properties (Fig. 9 ) [ 128,129 ]. Khalil et al. [ 130 ] focused on understanding spin-charge conversion at the interface of a ferromagnet or antiferromagnet/metal in a bilayer device, using a yttrium iron garnet (YIG)/platinum (Pt) bilayer system. They employed in STEM and high-resolution EELS to correlate atomic structure with spin-charge conversion properties in operational devices. Advanced monochromated STEM provided the capability to visualize materials and atomic structures with electron beams at atomic scales, complemented by EELS offering energy resolution of 10 meV or below. This technique has recently been employed to map magnons at atomic scales [ 131 ]. EELS benefits from high spatial resolution and provides detailed elemental and chemical state information, crucial for characterizing the spin state of SACs. However, it also presents challenges such as complex data analysis and potential electron radiation damage. It is most suitable for ultrathin samples and materials tolerant to high-energy electron beams, particularly for in situ dynamic studies. EELS remains a powerful technical tool that significantly enhances understanding of the electronic structure and spin state dynamics of SACs. 4.3 Mössbauer spectroscopy Mössbauer spectroscopy is a powerful technique that examines changes in nuclear energy levels with extraordinary precision, offering deep insights into atomic states. Nuclei at the core of atoms are remarkably sensitive to variations in their immediate surroundings, making this method highly effective for analyzing elemental oxidation states, local magnetic fields, lattice symmetry, and vibrations. This capability enables researchers to determine atomic compositions and electronic structures in complex materials, especially those relevant to SA catalysis [ 132,133 ]. The technique is suitable for elements and solid samples that exhibit the Mössbauer effect, encompassing important catalytic elements such as Fe, Sn, Ir, Ru, Sb, Pt, Au, and others. Mössbauer spectroscopy utilizes gamma rays, providing substantial penetration depth for in situ studies. Moreover, it is relatively cost-effective and accessible in terms of instrumentation compared to other spectroscopic methods, enhancing its utility in both research and industrial applications [ 134,135 ]. Spin state transitions are a molecular phenomenon that depends on intermolecular interactions and can occur in TM complexes with octahedral coordination spheres around the central atom [ 136 ]. In Mössbauer spectra, Fe ions with different spin states can be distinguished by different isomer shifts and quadrupole splittings [ 137,138 ]. The LS states of Fe2+ and Fe3+ have lower isomer shifts, and the quadrupole splittings of LS Fe2+ compounds are lower than those of the related HS states, while the quadrupole splittings of LS Fe3+ compounds are higher. For example, Liu et al. [ 139 ] used Mössbauer spectroscopy to verify the spin state transition strategy they proposed, mediated by axial Fe-O-Ti ligands (Fig. 10 ). As shown by the Mössbauer spectrum (57Fe) of the polymer-like material, the D1 and D2 peaks can be attributed to the IS and LS structures of Fe3+, respectively. Additionally, the D1 area (72.6%) of o-MQFe-10:20:5 is higher than that of PQD-Fe (34.6%), confirming the spin state transition from low spin to intermediate spin of Fe3+ [ 139 ]. In situ Mössbauer spectroscopy has proven invaluable in guiding the design and optimization of spin catalysts [ 140 ], particularly for systems involving iron-containing SACs like Fe-N-C. Chen et al. [ 65 ] demonstrated a method to enhance the presence of LS Fe3+ sites using sulfur-doped Fe1-N-C catalysts. Through in situ 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy, they investigated the spin polarization configurations and dynamic behavior under ORR conditions. Their findings highlighted that introducing a small amount of sulfur (1.3 wt%) into the Fe1-N-C catalyst significantly increased the content of LS Fe3+. This modification was crucial as it enhanced the desorption process of OH*, thereby improving the overall ORR activity. Interestingly, further increases in sulfur doping led to a decrease in the content of LS Fe3+, suggesting a nuanced relationship between sulfur doping and catalytic performance optimization [ 65 ]. Sougrati et al. [ 141 ] conducted a detailed 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy study between ambient temperature and 5 K to enhance the absolute quantity of different iron species in Fe-N-C electrocatalysts for reducing oxygen electrochemically. By quantifying the various Lamb-Mössbauer f LM factors of the different iron species obtained from the absolute absorption region as a function of temperature, these measurements allowed us to confirm that most ORR-active iron atoms exist in the form of FeN4/C within the catalyst. These iron atoms are present in either a low-spin or intermediate-spin state, and appropriate adjustments in the preparation methods help to avoid the formation of excessive Fe phases. Mössbauer spectroscopy offers several advantages in characterizing SACs. It boasts high sensitivity and provides detailed electronic and magnetic information, particularly for samples containing Mössbauer-active nuclei such as 57Fe. This technique is especially suitable for studying spin states and chemical environments in iron-containing catalysts. However, Mössbauer spectroscopy is limited by its applicability to specific elements and requires specialized equipment, which can be costly [ 142 ]. Overall, Mössbauer spectroscopy remains a powerful tool for researchers aiming to understand and optimize the electronic and magnetic properties of SACs, offering critical insights that can guide the development of more efficient catalytic materials [ 143 ]. 5 Conclusion and outlook This article focuses on the theory of spin catalysis, the research progress in the regulation of spin in SACs, and the characterization methods for spin. We believe that adjusting the spin state of both the catalyst and the reactants can significantly enhance catalytic performance. Additionally, we have explored how spin-related electron transfer and orbital interactions influence the relationship between SACs and electrocatalysis. The advantages, limitations, and applicable scenarios of three commonly used spin SAC methods are also discussed in this article. With the rise of spin catalysis, we have introduced some advanced characterization techniques and regulation strategies that can help us gain a deeper understanding of the spin state transformation during the catalytic reaction of catalysts. Although the research on spin state transitions is still in its early stages, future research directions can focus on the following aspects: (1) Exploring new strategies for spin state regulation: Given that enhanced catalytic performance stems from multiple factors, it is crucial to devise systems exclusively aimed at optimizing the spin state for mechanistic research. Future endeavors should also explore more effective strategies for regulating spin states. This can be achieved through rational catalyst structure design, the introduction of external fields (e.g., magnetic fields), or by controlling reaction conditions meticulously. Such approaches will enable precise control over the spin state, thereby generating novel ideas and methodologies for enhancing catalyst performance. (2) In-depth study of the effects of different spin states on catalytic reactions: Currently, there is insufficient research examining the impact of various spin states on catalytic reactions comprehensively. Future investigations should integrate advanced techniques to delve deeper into the regulatory mechanisms by which different spin states influence catalytic reactions. Special emphasis should be placed on assessing whether spin state transitions modify the adsorption configurations and reaction pathways of intermediates, aiming to gain a thorough understanding of spin's influence on catalytic processes. (3) Developing new spin characterization techniques: The future of research will focus significantly on advancing spin characterization techniques. These new methods will enable real-time monitoring and quantitative analysis of spin state transformations at active sites, utilizing techniques such as in situ X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS), in situ ESR, and in situ Mössbauer spectroscopy. These approaches will elucidate the precise state of active sites and their evolution during catalytic reactions. Establishing these in situ characterization methods holds immense promise for unraveling spin catalysis mechanisms and guiding the design of innovative spin catalysts. (4) Spin quantization calculation and simulation: Future research will leverage advanced quantum chemistry calculations and simulations to precisely predict electronic structures, magnetic properties, and reaction pathways under varying spin states. This approach offers theoretical guidance for experimental studies, helping to reduce the time and cost associated with experimental screening. Additionally, by applying quantum mechanical models, researchers can gain deeper insights into how spin states influence the microscopic mechanisms of catalytic reactions, thereby laying a solid theoretical foundation for the design of innovative catalysts. (5) The interaction between spin and surface chemistry: Surface chemistry is pivotal in catalytic processes, as the surface adsorption behavior of catalysts directly influences reactant activation and intermediate conversion efficiency. Future research should prioritize understanding how spin states regulate interactions between catalyst surfaces and reactants or intermediates. For instance, varying spin states can alter the electronic structure of active sites, affecting the adsorption strength, adsorption configuration, and subsequent reaction pathways of molecules. By finely tuning the spin state, it is possible to achieve precise control over catalytic reaction steps, thereby optimizing overall catalytic efficiency. Spin SA catalysis is poised to become a pivotal area of research in the future. Despite its challenges, we are optimistic that researchers can innovate to create more efficient and stable catalysts, thereby addressing the pressing issue of energy scarcity. We envision that this review will foster advancements in spin state transitions and pave the way for the rational design of next-generation high-performance catalysts. coredata.dc:description: To enhance the efficiency of green energy harvesting and pollutant degradation, significant efforts are focused on identifying highly effective catalysts. Metal-nitrogen-carbon single-atom catalysts (M-N-C SACs) have emerged as pivotal in catalysis due to their unique geometric structures, electronic states, and catalytic capabilities. Notably, the incorporation of magnetic elements at the active centers of these single-atom catalysts has garnered attention for their role in efficient electrochemical conversions. The orientation of spin states critically influences the adsorption and formation of reactants and intermediates, making the precise control of spin alignment and magnetic moments essential for reducing energy barriers and overcoming spin-related limitations, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. Thus, understanding the catalytic role of spin and modulating spin density at M-N-C single-atom centers holds profound fundamental and technological significance. In this review, we elucidate the fundamental mechanisms governing spin states and its influence in electrocatalysis. We then discuss various strategies for adjusting the spin states of active centers in the M-N-C SACs and the associated characterization techniques. Finally, we outline challenges and future perspectives of spin regulation for high-performance catalysts. This review provides deep insights into the micro-mechanisms of catalytic phenomena and offers a roadmap for designing spin-regulated catalysts for advanced energy applications.
